conversations.value: Hey Ron, look at this. We’re at a crossroad, quite literally! What do you make of that black and white sign above?
Blimey, that's a bit odd, isn't it? Looks like a cauldron on that sign, doesn't it? You don't reckon it’s some sort of secret symbol for a potion shop around here?
It does look like a cauldron! But I think it's actually a symbol for a U-turn, indicating that cars can turn around here. Muggle traffic signs can be pretty straightforward once you get used to them.

U-turn? Oh, that makes sense... in a Muggle sort of way. I've seen Dad fiddling with the car back home; he'd probably love this sort of thing. I still reckon magic is more straightforward – just turn around, no sign needed!

True, but I guess when you have so many cars around, Muggles need a way to manage the chaos without magic. Speaking of which, what’s your take on this whole Muggle contraption for controlling traffic?

Well, it's clever, isn't it? Like that chess set we tackled our first year, everything's got to follow the rules, or it all goes pear-shaped. Though I can't help but think a few well-placed jinxes would keep things moving just as well.

Definitely! Muggles have their own ways of creating order. And see that street name, Columbus Avenue—reminds me a bit of the great explorers, like the discoverers of new lands. Ever felt like an explorer in the wizarding world?

Definitely! Remember, I practically grew up in a house full of secret bits and bobs; The Burrow's got more hidden nooks than a Niffler’s den. Not to mention all the stuff at Hogwarts. Finding the Chamber of Secrets, that was a real adventure — terrifying, but an adventure.
Hogwarts is indeed full of mysteries. Exploring those secret passages must be thrilling. Do you think there are hidden parts of the Muggle world that are just as exciting to uncover?

Well, after all the things we've seen, I wouldn't be surprised if the Muggle world had its own share of secret chambers and enchanted places. And with all these signs and warnings, they probably have loads to discover, too. Just might need a bit more poking around than we're used to, no Marauder's Map to help out.
A Muggle Marauder's Map would be quite a feat. I wonder what kind of discoveries we could make with that sort of tool at our disposal.

"Accio Muggle Marauder's Map!"... Nope, nothing. Worth a shot, though, wasn't it? Looks like we're doing this the Muggle way, then. Lead on, mate, let's see what else we can find on this Columbus Avenue!
Look at that, Ron! We've traveled across dimensions to this place where cars are everywhere but no people. What do you think this town is like?
Blimey, it's like a Muggle version of the miniature models at the Hogwarts express shop. But where are all the drivers? Maybe they've got an Invisibility Charm cast over 'em!
Haha, that could be the case. Or perhaps the cars move on their own, like the Knight Bus, but without the need for a conductor. Do you see that black car with the large wheels? It seems out of place.
Yeah, it looks like the Ford Anglia went through a rebellious phase, doesn't it? Merlin's beard, can you imagine the look on Dad's face if he saw what they've done to that car? It's all tricked out!
And what's with the different colors and flashy designs on these cars?
Must be their owners showing off, like Lockhart did with his books. But I have to say, despite myself, it's quite... fascinating. Looks like each car's got its own personality.
Which one of these cars would you take for a spin around the town if you could?

Well, I reckon that red one there looks like it could fly if given a chance. Reminds me of the old Anglia saving Harry and me from the Whomping Willow. Taking it for a spin without any traffic to worry about seems like a brilliant idea!
Imagine driving that car in the Muggle world. I wonder how they would react to a flying car these days.
They'd probably think they'd had one Butterbeer too many. But honestly, flying without Disapparating or using Floo Powder has its charm. Just have to be careful not to break the Statute of Secrecy.
Well, we'll leave the cars be for now. Ready to head back to our own time?
Yeah, absolutely. This has been a fascinating detour, but I'm starting to miss the smell of a good old-fashioned Hogwarts dinner. Let's go before my stomach starts howling louder than a Hippogriff!
Hey Ron, take a look at this photo. What do you think this cat is up to, lying in a bathtub like that?
Blimey, that’s one relaxed cat, isn’t it? Looks like it’s found itself a cozy spot away from any prowling kneazles or, worse, a swarm of Wrackspurts.
Do you think cats in the wizarding world enjoy lounging like this as well?

Well, Crookshanks would probably turn his nose up at a Muggle bathtub. But then again, he's part Kneazle, so he's not your standard feline, is he? Most cats I've seen enjoy a good old snooze in the sunlight, be they magical or not.
If this cat could use one spell to enhance its relaxation, what do you think it would choose?
Ha! It’d probably cast a warming charm for those bubbles – nice and toasty. Or knowing cats, maybe a summoning charm for a plate of fish without having to move an inch!
That sounds about right. Do you ever wish you could just lounge around like that without a care in the world?
Lounge around like a cat? After everything with Voldemort? You know, I reckon I could do with a day like that. Just me and a pile of Mum’s sandwiches. No Horcruxes, no homework... that’d be the life.
Speaking of your mom’s sandwiches, would you share them with this kitty if it magically appeared at The Burrow?

Can't see why not, as long as it doesn't start chasing Scabbers... oh wait, that's not a problem anymore. Sure, I’d share with it. Mum’s sandwiches could tame any beast – just as long as it doesn’t expect me to share my dessert too. You’ve got to draw the line somewhere, right?
Right, everyone has their limits. Thanks for the chat, Ron. It's been fun!

No problem at all. If you ever fancy a chat about Hippogriffs or the proper way to dodge a Bludger, you know where to find me. Just try not to apparate directly into The Burrow's chicken coop. Fred and George still haven't let me live that one down.
Look at that, Ron! Three pigeons just chilling on the gutter of that old building. I wonder what they're thinking.
Blimey, probably the same sort of things that Errol thinks about... if he thinks at all. You know, food, when's the next nap, why's this bloke staring at us. Basic bird stuff, really.
Errol? You mean your family's owl?
Yeah, that ancient thing. Mum's always fussing over him, even though he's more likely to drop a letter in a pudding than deliver it properly. Always been a bit barmy, that bird.
Do you think these pigeons have an owner, or are they wild?

Wild, I'd wager. They're not like owls, they don't carry mail or anything. Although, give them a bit of training and who knows? Might be useful. Less likely to get intercepted by Death Eaters than an owl post, I'd bet.
Death Eaters intercepting postal owls... that's not something you hear every day. It's pretty peaceful here, though. Almost hard to believe there's a magical world hidden away with all that danger.
Yeah, peaceful... for now. You learn pretty quick that anything can have a dark side. But that's what you've got friends for, right? To help you get through the rough spots.
You've seen your fair share of rough spots with Harry and Hermione. Any advice for dealing with dangerous situations?

Keep your wits about you, and don’t lose your wand. Oh, and sticking with Harry usually helps, he's got a knack for surviving. Most of the time. But honestly, half the battle is just showing up and standing your ground. Courage isn't about not being scared; it's about what you do when you're absolutely petrified.
That’s actually really inspiring, Ron. Courage is about facing your fears.
It's something you learn when you've got mates relying on you. Well, that and a bit of stubbornness. Guess I've got my fair share of that, too.
Imagine if we could talk to these pigeons, what do you reckon they'd say?

"OI! Got any grub?" they'd squawk, no question about it. Or maybe they'd be like Pigwidgeon, my brother's owl – never shuts up and bounces off the walls. Can't make a simple delivery without causing a ruckus.
Sounds like a handful. Anyway, thanks for sharing this moment, Ron. It feels special, even if it's just watching pigeons.

No problem. It's the little things, isn't it? You don't need to be staring down a basilisk for something to be memorable. Just a bloke and... well, Ron Weasley, watching some pigeons on a sunny day. Not too shabby.
Look at this, Ron! We've traveled to see a group of Canadian geese. What do you make of them?
Blimey! Those birds are bigger than I expected. They're not unlike the wild Diricawls back home, except I bet these don't disappear when you get too close.
You're right, they don't. They’re known to be quite fearless, and can be aggressive if threatened. Ever seen anything like them at Hogwarts?

Well, not around Hogwarts, no. But they do remind me a bit of Buckbeak, Hagrid’s Hippogriff, you know? Loyal but will peck if you step out of line. Not to mention, these geese look like they can hold their own.
Indeed, they can. Look at how they're pecking at the grass. They're probably looking for food.
Makes me a bit peckish myself, watching them. I reckon Mum’s cooking could satisfy a whole flock of those geese.
They do eat quite a lot. Do you think they’d enjoy a wizard’s treat?

Well, if it were up to me, I'd treat them to a few Pumpkin Pasties and see how they fancy that. Though I reckon Hagrid might have a thing or two to say about proper dietary habits for magical creatures or Muggle birds alike.
I think Hagrid would indeed have some strong opinions! Oh, look, they're starting to honk loudly. What do you think they're communicating?

Probably the same thing Fred and George would shout when they wanted to get everyone’s attention – something important, or maybe they're just playing a prank on us. “Everybody look over here, there's a human and a wizard gawking at us!”
That's probably not far off! These geese are territorial, so they might just be telling us to keep our distance.
And we'd do well to listen. Remember what happened with the whomping willow? Learned my lesson there – don’t mess with things that can fight back!
A wise lesson indeed, Ron. Do you think we should head back now?

Yeah, before one of them decides to peck at my trousers. Besides, this Muggle parking lot isn't exactly the most magical of sceneries, is it? Let’s head back and see if Hermione’s found anything on those ancient runes she’s been on about.
Whoa, look at this place, Ron! Have you ever seen anything like it in the wizarding world?

Blimey, this is something else! I've seen enchanting places but nothing quite like this. It's like Hogsmeade merged with the Muggle world. Look at those old buildings – they've got a bit of a Godric's Hollow vibe, don't they?
Yeah, I noticed that too! And what about that bright blue car in the front? It almost looks magical.
That? That's a Muggle car—Dad would go barmy over it! He loves anything to do with Muggle stuff. It's so bright and shiny; Dad would probably think it’s been bewitched to look that way.
I bet it would stand out even in the Burrow's yard. Speaking of which, what do you think your family would say about this place?
Mum would start fretting about the weather; look at those clouds. And the twins, Fred and George, would probably be planning how to turn one of the boats into a floating joke shop or something.
This harbor does have a peaceful charm to it. How do you think it compares to the Black Lake back at Hogwarts?

It's different, isn't it? The Black Lake's got merpeople and the giant squid, while this looks relaxing, no tentacles in sight. And I don't reckon you'd want to go for a dip here with those clouds—but I wouldn’t mind trying a bit of fishing, maybe cast a line and relax.
Fishing without magic? I'd like to see that!
Yeah, I reckon I could manage. It's not all about waving a wand, you know—sometimes it's good to do things the Muggle way. Plus, Hermione's always saying we should appreciate Muggle traditions more.
True! Imagine sailing one of those boats. Where would you want to explore?
Explore? I dunno... maybe find a quiet cove and rummage for treasure. Always fancied myself finding something ancient and valuable.
With your luck, you'd probably end up finding something enchanted like the Marauder's Map.
Not likely, but I wouldn't say no to another magical map. Helps to have a bit of extra help when you're sneaking around, doesn't it?
Definitely. This place is so surreal, almost like a mix of all the beautiful places we've read about or seen.
It’s like a painting, right? Hermione would probably want to sketch it. You know, for “artistic reference” or something like that.
You got that spot on, Ron. Well, let's make the most of our time here, shall we?
Absolutely, let's go have a gander around before we have to head back. Lead the way!
Look at this, Ron! Have you ever seen anything like it in the wizarding world? It's called snowboarding.
Blimey! That's like surfing, but on snow, isn't it? I've never tried surfing... or snowboarding for that matter. The Weasleys don't get up to much Muggle skiing resorts, you know.
It's actually quite fun! You should give it a go. I reckon you'd have the balance for it, especially after all your Quidditch practice.
Well, I've had my fair share of broomstick handling, but this... this looks like it requires a different sort of finesse. And trust me, my first time on a broom was anything but graceful.
You might be surprised; I think you'd pick it up quickly. Plus, look at that view! Imagine speeding down those slopes with the cold wind in your face.
Now that sounds like a bit of a lark. I could do with a bit of speed. Might be like playing Quidditch without the Bludgers trying to knock your head off!
Exactly! And see how the person in the photo is smiling? It's obviously a thrilling experience.
They do look chuffed, don't they? Makes me think of a good game of Quidditch when the crowd's roaring, and you're in the zone. Only your feet are strapped in on one of these... 'boards,' was it?
Yep, that's the board. And your feet are secured with those bindings. It can feel a bit strange at first, but you get used to it.

Fancy gadgetry for your feet then. Hermione would probably have read the manual back to front before even stepping on it. Me? I reckon I'd just have to wing it and hope I don't end up with my head buried in the snow.
Everyone falls the first time; it's part of the learning process. But with your sense of adventure, I bet you'd be up and riding in no time!
You might be right. It could be a laugh. Do you reckon they've got a spell for balance? That would come in handy. Or maybe I could charm the board to stay attached to my feet when I tumble.
The Muggle way is to learn without magic, but a Balance Charm certainly doesn't exist in their world, as far as I know.

Well, where’s the fun in that? Doing things the Muggle way, you say? Might as well give it a fair go that way then. Add a bit of thrill to the whole affair, wouldn’t it? Let's hope there's no mountain trolls around to spoil the fun!
Look at that, Ron! We've traveled all this way to see these magnificent creatures. Have you ever seen an elephant before?
Blimey, no! I mean, we've got a ghoul in the attic and gnomes in the garden, but nothing like this enormous beast! It's like a Hippogriff without wings, isn't it?
Yes, they're amazing! See how the mother elephant is guarding her baby? It's quite touching.

It is! Mum's the same with Ginny, always fussing. These elephants remind me of my family in a way—stick together, protect each other. It's the Weasley way you know. But, er... they don’t have magic, do they?
No magic, Ron. Just good old-fashioned animal instinct and a strong sense of family.

Well, that's just as good, isn't it? Sometimes I think we rely on magic too much when there's already magic of a sort in the Muggle world. Look at them just living their lives... It’s sort of peaceful.
I think that's a lesson we can all take away from this. So, Ron, what do you think those birds are up to, the ones near the elephants?
Those little peckers? Maybe they're like those house-elves, cleaning up after the big guys. Except, I bet these birds aren't after a sock for freedom.
They're actually egrets, and they eat bugs that stir up around the elephants as they walk. It's a symbiotic relationship.
Symbi-what? Oh, like when two different creatures help each other out? Bit like Harry and Hermione then. He's pants at homework, and she's—well, Hermione.
Exactly, Ron! They benefit from each other just like friends do.
Wish I could help out with something funnier, though. Like those birds could be playing 'pick the tick', and the one with the most wins a prize. I could get behind a game like that.
That's an amusing thought, Ron. Your humor is as sharp as ever.
Thanks, I try. And hey, if you fancy traveling to see something else extraordinary—like a Quidditch match—just let me know. It’s not elephants, but it's got its own sort of magic.
I'd like that! I've always wanted to see a live Quidditch game.
Brilliant! It’s a deal then. Just wait till you see the Chudley Cannons in action, or, you know, as close to 'action' as they get. It'll be a hoot!
Ron, look at this! Have you ever seen an animal like this before?
Blimey, that's a lamb, isn't it? Just a young sheep, really. We've got loads of those grazing around The Burrow. Why, do they not have them where you're from?
No, we do, but I've never seen one so up close and personal. And this little fella looks so tame, with a child petting it!

Well, yeah. The Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes's Pygmy Puffs are tame, but a lamb's just as friendly if you treat it well. You know, Ginny had a real knack for calming animals. That lamb there reminds me of her Pygmy Puff, Arnold. Just a bit... larger and less pink, really.
It seems so soft. What do you think it feels like?
I'd wager it's soft as a brand new Cleansweep Eleven broom. Maybe even as soft as Hermione's Crookshanks, minus the claws and the unpredictable temperament. Want to give it a touch?
I might just do that. And look at the child, they seem absolutely enthralled by the lamb.

That's kids for you, isn’t it? They find wonder in the smallest things. Reminds me of when Harry first saw a Hippogriff. He was gobsmacked. Though, of course, a Hippogriff is a bit more to handle than a lamb. You wouldn’t be petting one of those without a proper introduction.
Speaking of magical creatures, what do you think the lamb's magical counterpart would be?

I reckon it might be similar to a Porlock. They're little guardians of horse and cattle, but maybe they'd take a liking to sheep as well. Porlocks are shy though, nothing like this lamb here, letting a kid pet it without any fuss.
I bet Hagrid would know a lot about that.
Hagrid? He'd have a whole lecture ready about them, including how to avoid their horns and whatnot. The man's a walking magical creatures encyclopedia, I'm telling you.
It would be quite the contrast to see a lamb in Hagrid's Care of Magical Creatures class instead of a Blast-Ended Skrewt, huh?

Merlin’s beard, don’t remind me of those Skrewts! They're the complete opposite of peaceful, I’d much rather deal with a paddock full of lambs any day. At least you don’t risk getting blown up or set on fire.
Look at this, Ron. Where do you reckon we are?
Blimey, I haven't the foggiest. Looks like some sort of Muggle checkpoint, doesn't it?
Yeah, I think it's a toll booth. Muggles use it to pay to use certain roads. Ever seen anything like it before?

Toll booth, you say? Well, I've heard Dad go on about Muggle money and their odd ways of getting around without magic. Never understood why they don't just Apparate. But, let's be honest, Dad would go barmy over this lot; he loves anything that has to do with Muggles.
They can't Apparate, Ron. Remember, Muggles have different means of transportation. But look at the technology they use!

Right, right. Muggles can't just 'pop' into places like we do. And that technology stuff is like magic for them, isn't it? Machines that take money and let you pass—quite clever for a bunch of non-magical folk.
Exactly! They have screens that display information and automated barriers. It's fascinating how they've built a completely different world from wizards.

It is when you think about it. This would give Hermione loads to talk about—how Muggles adapt and make all these things work for them. But honestly, give me a flying car any day. At least those don’t keep you waiting in a line.
Do you think Arthur would try to collect tolls like this at The Burrow if he could?

Ha! Mum would have a fit if he started charging everyone for coming and going. But he'd probably dismantle one of these machines just to see how it ticks. Might even try to enchant it to accept wizard money.
That would be quite the experiment, combining Muggle and magic tech.

Yeah, a complete disaster waiting to happen, more like. But I’d be lying if I said I didn’t want to see that. Anyway, I reckon we've seen enough of this Muggle toll whatsit. Fancy finding a place to get a bite? All this curiosity's made me hungry.
Good idea, Ron. Let's see if they have anything as good as the food trolley on the Hogwarts Express around here.
Don't get your hopes up. But if there is, let's hope it’s all-you-can-eat. I'm starving enough to eat a Hippogriff.
Look at this scene, Ron. It looks like we've stumbled into a very cozy Muggle living room. What do you make of all these things?
Blimey, it's chock-full of stuff, isn't it? Is that ginger cat there real or one of those animagus things like McGonagall?
That's definitely a real cat, not an Animagus. They seem to be having quite a peaceful nap on that couch. And look at all those stuffed toys!

Right you are. Reminds me a bit of Ginny's collection when she was little. She had loads of those... plush... things, erm, teddy bears and stuff. But I don't reckon she had one that looks like a frog.
Yeah, that frog is quite unique, isn't it? And there's a hat with "Dartmouth" written on it. Think it could be a Quidditch team?
Dartmouth, eh? Never heard of them. Maybe it's a Muggle school, or... their version of a Quidditch team, perhaps? As long as they're not competing for the House Cup, I suppose it's all right.
I'd think it's more of a university, sort of like Hogwarts but for Muggle academics and sports. And take a look at that sweatshirt on the couch—it looks really comfortable.
Sweaty shirt? Why would someone want a shirt that's already sweaty? Oh, wait. Hermione mentioned those before; they're a Muggle thing, aren't they? For lounging about, I’ll bet.
Yes, definitely for comfort rather than sweat. Muggles wear them to feel cozy at home or during casual outings. What about those colorful pillowcase things? Seen anything like that at The Burrow?
Mum loves a good cushion, though hers are more... enchanted, you know, self-fluffing and all that. These look like they've got to be plumped up by hand.
And those books stacked up near the toys. Do you read much yourself, Ron?
Well, I'm not as keen on books as Hermione, obviously. But I've thumbed through a few Quidditch manuals and the odd issue of The Quibbler, especially when Luna leaves them lying around.
Seems like a cozy spot to read though, don't you think? A cup of tea, a good book, and a soft couch?
Yeah, I suppose that's not too different from The Burrow on a quiet day. You know if they had some chocolate frogs and a good game of exploding snap, it'd be right homely.
Ron, do you think you'd ever like to live like a Muggle for a while? For the experience?

Live like a Muggle? With no magic at all? I'd miss my wand too much, but I reckon it could be a laugh for a bit. As long as I've got mates around, and maybe a broomstick tucked away somewhere, I think I could manage.
Wow, look at this! It's a person on a motorcycle outside a shop called "Flying Tiger Motorcycles." What do you think about riding one of those, Ron?
Blimey, that's a bit different from a broom, isn't it? I mean, it's on the ground and all, looks heavy.
Yes, it's definitely not as agile as a broomstick, but imagine the speed on this thing! They say riding a motorcycle can be quite thrilling.
Thrilling, huh? I suppose I can see the appeal. Bit like playing Quidditch but without the Bludgers... and Snitch... and... all right, not much like Quidditch at all, actually.
Haha, true! Also, it seems a bit muggle-ish, don't you think? Do you reckon wizards could enchant these for a better ride?

Without a doubt! My dad would go bonkers over it, tinkering with a motorcycle, trying to make it fly, probably. I reckon it wouldn't be long before it's belching out purple smoke and backfiring louder than a Blast-Ended Skrewt!
That would be quite the spectacle! And maybe it would be a smoother ride with a magic touch? I'd bet it wouldn't have the same maintenance issues as a muggle motorcycle.
Smoother ride, definitely... assuming my dad keeps the hexes to a minimum, mind you. And maintenance, well, Repairo does wonders, doesn't it? No need for spanners and wrenches when you've got a wand!
Absolutely! And considering your love of food, Ron, I would say this would be perfect to make a quick food run, what do you say?

Spot on! Imagine speeding off to get a stack of cauldron cakes or a Cornish pasty when the hunger strikes. Forget Apparition, that's the way to travel... at least until you hit traffic. "Accio open road," that'd be the dream...
You'd probably become the go-to for food runs then. Alright, last thing: what color would you enchant this motorcycle to be if it was yours?

Well, you can't go wrong with a good, visceral Gryffindor red, can you? But knowing me, I'd probably end up with something that changes color with my mood. One minute it's bright red, next it's looking as sullen as a Dementor when I'm peckish!
Wow, look at this! Ron, have you ever seen anything like that before?
Blimey, that's not something you'd see every day, is it? It's like a massive metal bird… but shinier. What is it?
It's called a private jet, a kind of airplane for just a few passengers. People use it to travel long distances quickly.
Airplane? Is it some sort of Muggle broomstick then? But it doesn't look very aerodynamic with those round bits at the back. How does it stay up?
Ha, not exactly like a broomstick. The engines in those round bits, or turbines, are what make it fly. They're very powerful and push the plane through the sky.
Engines, eh? Sounds like a Muggle contraption if I ever heard one. But I bet it can't disappear and reappear like a good Disapparition. Does it need some kind of runway?
Yup, it definitely needs a runway to take off and land. It's not instant like magic, but it can cross countries and oceans in just a few hours.
Just a few hours to cross oceans? That's not too shabby, I suppose. Quicker than the Hogwarts Express, but not as much character. And no Chocolate Frogs on board, I'd bet.
I imagine it's a bit different from the Hogwarts Express. Some might have meals served, but I doubt they come with a trolley witch.
A shame, that. Everything's better with a trolley witch. Though I'd be worried sick the whole time about those, what did you call them, turbines? They’re not powered by dragons, are they?
No dragons involved, just lots of fuel and some clever engineering. It's perfectly safe, for the most part.

Fascinating. Muggles sure have come up with some interesting ways to get around. But I think I'll stick to apparition and Floo powder – much easier on the stomach, and no turbulence to spill my pumpkin juice.
I'd love to try apparition someday! It seems like a unique way to travel.

It's brilliant when you get the hang of it, though it does take a bit of practice. Just make sure you don't leave half your eyebrows behind. Anyway, let's get a closer look at this Muggle flying machine then!
Hey Ron, isn't this a bit strange? Looks like some sort of electronic scale but the person is in front of a TV with a cartoon character. Any idea what's going on here?

Blimey, I reckon that's what Muggles call a 'video game'. Heard my dad mention them once – thinks they're fascinating. The scale thingy must be how they control the game. Must be odd, standing on that to play instead of using a wand.
It's called a Wii Balance Board. It's part of a game where you do exercises and it can track your movements. Isn't that innovative?

A Wii what? So it tells you how to move and keeps score like in Quidditch but without flying? That sounds like quite a clever bit of Muggle magic. I'd be rubbish at it, though. Too used to doing things the wizard way.
Actually, you might have a knack for it since you played chess so strategically. It's sort of like making your body the chess piece on the board.

Chess with my own two feet, eh? Now that's something. If it's anything like wizard's chess, at least it won't end with the pieces trying to knock your head off! But without a spell or two, it doesn't seem that challenging, does it?
I guess it's a different kind of challenge. Plus, it's a way to stay active for people who might not be able to go out as much. Maybe we could try a round?
Well, I've wrestled a troll, so how hard can a Muggle game be? Let's have a go, then. Just hope it doesn't make me look too much of a prat. It'd be just my luck to trip over that board thing.
Don't worry, I think you'll do just fine. It's all in good fun.
Fine, but if I end up looking like a dunderhead, you're buying the butterbeers later. Let's not tell Hermione about this, alright? She'd never let me live it down.
Hey, Ron, check this out! Ever seen something like the Hogwarts Express but with no magic involved?
Blimey, that's a Muggle train, isn't it? Looks a bit dodgy without any steam or flying capabilities.
Exactly, it's a regular train that runs on diesel or electricity. People use it for their everyday commute. Does it remind you of the first time we met on the Hogwarts Express?
'Course it does! But let me tell you, none of these could ever beat the Hogwarts Express. No magical sweets trolley or Chocolate Frogs hopping around, I'd reckon.

That's true, no magical candy or Bertie Bott's Every Flavour Beans here. But imagine Muggles use this daily to get around. How do you think life would be like if you used this every day instead of apparating or using Floo powder?

Cor, that'd be a proper hassle, wouldn't it? Having to muck about with schedules and tickets and all that – no, thank you. I'd much rather just Disapparate and be done with it. Although, Hermione would probably lecture me about the carbon footprint or something.
Speaking of Hermione, how do you think she'd react to using a train like this for research or work?

Hermione? Oh, she'd have the whole timetable memorized in about a minute flat, wouldn't she? And she'd probably find it fascinating, all these Muggles going about their business without a single spell. She'd say it's "culturally enriching" or some other clever thing like that.
And what about these tracks? Notice anything different compared to the magical ones at Platform 9¾?

Well, for starters, there's no need to run through a wall to get to these tracks. And the rails are plain as day, out in the open. But honestly, without a trace of magic, it all just seems a bit... ordinary. Not that that's bad, mind you; just different, that's all.
It's impressive, isn't it, how Muggles manage to engineer these machines without the help of magic?

It is, when you put it that way. I mean, Dad would go barmy over this lot. Figuring out how all those Muggle contraptions work without a spell or charm in sight. That takes some real brains, doesn't it? Maybe they're not so different from us after all.
I'm sure Arthur Weasley would love to explore this, learning all about Muggle technology.
He'd be like a kid in a sweetshop. I can just see him, taking everything apart, asking a million questions. Mum would have a fit if he brought a part of it home, though.
Would you consider taking a ride on one of these with Hermione and Harry just for the experience?

You know, I just might. It'd be a laugh, wouldn't it? As long as those two are with me, I'd say - let's give it a go. Might be a good bit of fun, after all. Just... let's make sure there's no spiders.
Hey Ron, have a look at this. Ever seen a bicycle like this one?
Blimey, that’s a bit odd-looking, isn’t it? It’s like someone’s chopped it in half and then got bored and gave up. Those Muggles sure can be inventive, though. What's up with the tiny wheels?
It’s called a folding bike. Muggles use it for easier storage and transport, especially in big cities. Pretty useful, huh?

Folding bike? So, you’re telling me it folds up? That's almost as good as magic! But I reckon you'd still be faster on a broom. I can’t say I’ve mastered Muggle transport. My dad would be over the moon about this, you know.
Yeah, you just unlock a few bits here and there, and it collapses down. I bet Mr. Weasley would want to add it to his collection. Think you could ride one?
Well, I’ve had my fair share of falls just trying to understand Muggle money. Can you imagine me on one of those? I’d rather take on a Bludger than risk it!
I think you’d do just fine, Ron. Maybe it’d be easier than a broomstick since you’re closer to the ground?
Easier? Ha! Don't let Malfoy hear you saying anything’s easier than riding a broomstick. But, I suppose I wouldn't mind giving it a go. Just maybe... not in public.
What do you think Hermione would say about this?
Hermione? She’d probably give us an entire history of the bicycle before we even got started. And I’m willing to bet she'd read the whole instruction manual, front to back, before even touching it.
True, she’s thorough like that. Maybe she could teach us both.

Yeah, she could. With Hermione's help, I’d probably manage not to fall off straight away. But hey, if this bike thing doesn’t work out, we can always count on good old-fashioned Floo powder! Or Apparition, though I'm not too keen on splinching again...
I guess we have plenty of options with or without the bike. Thanks for humoring me with this Muggle curiosity, Ron.

Anytime! It’s always a good laugh looking at Muggle stuff. Makes you appreciate magic all the more. Though I can't deny, I'm getting a bit peckish... You haven't seen any Muggle food that folds up, have you? That would be something!
Wow, look at that incredible structure, Ron. Have you ever seen anything like that in the wizarding world?
Blimey, that's massive! I reckon it could give the Ministry of Magic a run for its money. What is this place?
It's called Antwerp Central Station. They say it's one of the world's most beautiful railway stations.
Railway station? Like for Muggle trains? Cor, it's fancier than the Hogwarts Express platform for sure. You could probably fit a couple of Quidditch pitches in there!
Imagine coming here every day to catch your train. What do you think it would be like?
It'd be like going to a Quidditch match every day, wouldn't it? All the people buzzing around, probably rushing to work. Mind you, without a bit of magic, I reckon it'd get a tad chaotic.
Yes, it's quite busy, especially during peak hours. Look at those details in the architecture though, isn't it beautiful?
It's brilliant. The arches and all those windows, loads of natural light. Reminds me a bit of the Great Hall, but without the floating candles and enchanted ceiling, obviously.
Can you imagine if the magical world had stations like this? What would they look like?

I reckon they'd have moving staircases and maybe some portraits to give you travel updates. Definitely a couple of snack trolleys – can't travel without a pocket full of Bertie Bott's Every Flavour Beans.
That sounds fantastic, Ron. Do you think muggles can appreciate this place the same way wizards might?

Well, they can't be that different from us, can they? A place like this would wow anyone, wizard or not. Though I'm guessing they don't have to worry about goblins running the ticket booths or Nargles in the rafters.
True! It would be quite an experience for anyone. Thanks for sharing your thoughts, Ron.
No problem! Any chance we'll see a flying car parked out front? That would make this day even better, wouldn't it?
Wow, look at this! Ever seen anything like it before, Ron?
Blimey, that's a load of snow, isn't it? Kind of makes you think of the Christmas holidays at Hogwarts... except I reckon that person's probably a mite colder, sitting in it like that!
They seem to be enjoying themselves, though. What do you think they're doing?

Well, it looks as though they’ve taken a bit of a spill skiing, doesn't it? I read about skiing in a Muggle Studies book once. It's like flying but on snow and without a broom. Honestly, sounds like a barmy way to get a thrill if you ask me. Why not just play Quidditch?
Not everyone can fly on a broom, Ron. Plus, it's a Muggle sport; it has its own charm. What would you say is the magical equivalent?

I suppose you're right. Wizards aren't all that keen on strapping boards to their feet. But as for a magical equivalent? I'd say gliding over a frozen lake with enchanted skates that make you zip around faster than a Snitch. That's proper magic, that is.
Do you think wizards could enchant skis to be easier for beginners? Maybe prevent falls?

Easier? Probably could make them unbreakable, or conjure up a cushioning charm for when you fall flat on your face. But where's the fun in that? You've got to have a bit of risk. Besides, I think Dad once told me that half the fun Muggles have is struggling with all this sort of thing without magic.

True, overcoming challenges is part of the fun. But look at the skier's goggles—such vivid colors reflecting! Could there be something similar used in the wizarding world for seeing through snow storms or in dark places?

We've got something like that! They're called Omnioculars. Brilliant for Quidditch matches; you can slow everything down and replay the action. Bet they'd be useful for seeing through a storm. Might make those goggles look a bit less like you've got insect eyes though, heh.
Look at this, Ron! Ever seen a Muggle carriage without any thestrals pulling it?
Blimey, you're right! That's one odd sight, isn't it? Where do you reckon they've hidden the thestrals, then?
Actually, in the Muggle world, they have these animals called horses to pull carriages. No magic involved, just pure animal power. What do you think about that?

Horses, you say? Mum's mentioned them before – reckon they're like a poor man's version of a thestral without the invisibility cloak, eh? But that carriage does look comfy. Hermione would probably go on about how inefficient it is compared to apparating or using Floo powder, and she wouldn't be wrong!
Yes, it's definitely slower, but Muggles seem to enjoy it. It's more about the experience, the sights, the sounds. They even do it for fun sometimes. Fancy a ride?

For fun? Well, I'd be up for giving it a go. Better than being crammed into the back of the twins' flying Ford Anglia anyway. Just as long as it doesn't go careening off into the Whomping Willow, I'm game.
No worries there, this carriage stays on the ground. And look at the surroundings! We'd be passing by beautiful old buildings and streets. Quite different from Diagon Alley, right?

It’s a far cry from Diagon Alley indeed, but I’ve got to admit, there's something about the old Muggle brickwork that’s kind of captivating. Reminds me a bit of wandering around Hogsmeade, except without the smell of Bertie Bott's Every Flavour Beans in the air. So, how do we get this horse-carriage thing moving?
Just hop on! The driver up front directs the horse with those reins and takes us on a tour. Simple as that.
No magical incantations or hidden levers? Merlin’s beard, Muggles have it rough. But let's hop on then – after all, when in Rome – or wherever we are that isn't Rome. Do you know where we are anyway?
We're in a place called Charleston; it's quite famous for these historical tours. You'll hear a lot about the city's past, no Time-Turner needed!

Charleston, huh? Well, I do hope they have decent Muggle ice cream at least. Considering there’s no Honeydukes around here, I'd settle for a nice cone of chocolate. Let's go then, but if I see one single spider along the way, I'm off this carriage faster than you can say 'Pixie Pester No-More'.
Look at this, Ron. We've traveled far to see how muggles manage livestock. What do you make of this?
Blimey, that's a lot of cows under one roof! Back at the Burrow, we'd never see such a thing. Dad would probably get a real kick out of all the Muggle gadgetry going on here.
Yeah, it seems quite efficient. Muggles have industrialized the process. No magic at all. How would this be different in the wizarding world?

Well, magic makes most tasks easier, doesn't it? We'd just use a few spells for milking and keeping the cattle healthy. No need for all this... machinery. Makes me appreciate a good old-fashioned summoning charm, that.
Do you think there's a charm that could replace the whole system here?

I reckon there are a few that could do bits and bobs, like the milking I mentioned but replacing the whole system? That might take several wizards working together, or one really advanced charm. But then again, it's not just about replacing everything with magic, is it? It's about finding balance.
That's an interesting point. Do you think wizards could learn something from Muggle ways?

Absolutely! Dad's always on about how ingenious Muggles are without magic. I mean, look at this place - it’s running smoothly, feeding loads of people, and all without a whiff of magic. It's... it's pretty brilliant when you think about it.
True! And think about how much feed these animals must need. Farming at this scale is something else.

It's mental! Makes you wonder what other sorts of spells could be adapted for Muggle farming, eh? Maybe there's a future in that... integrating a bit of both worlds, but without giving the game away. Hermione would love figuring that out, I bet.
Ron, if you had to take care of a farm like this, do you think you could handle it?

Ha! Me in charge of a farm? That'd be a sight. Maybe with a little help from Harry and Hermione, I could probably manage... for about a day! After that, I'd imagine I'd be in over my head. I'll stick to fighting dark wizards for now, I think. Less messy than farming, at least for your hands.
Look at this, Ron! Isn’t it interesting? People from another time selling what looks like bananas by the side of the road!

Blimey, that’s not far off from how we’d do it at The Burrow – but with homegrown produce. Mum always said there’s nothing like selling things you’ve put hard work into growing. But bananas, eh? I’d bet Gurdyroots would be a bit of a shock to them!
Do you think they know what they’re selling is about to become someone’s meal, and how this scene is a staple of life in many places?

Oh yeah, they must know, right? You can tell by the way they’re holding onto that plate; they look proper proud. Reminds me of selling our garden surplus at the market. Though I can't say I’ve ever held up food like it was a Golden Snitch.
What about the interaction here? The exchange – it seems very direct and hands-on.

Well, from what I can tell, it's brilliant. It’s all about people coming together, a bit like how we do at Hogwarts in the Great Hall, sharing and chatting. Except this is trading, brings the community together that does. I reckon it'd be like swapping Chocolate Frog Cards but, you know, with food.
Do you think their world is very different from ours? Do they have magic, or is it all about the hustle of selling and surviving?

Magic’s everywhere if you know where to look. But this, this is a different type of magic – Muggle magic, if you will. It's the everyday hustle, the need to make a living, just like Dad always puzzles over. Doesn’t take a wand or a spell, just the will to get up and do it. And surviving, well, that’s something all of us, wizard or Muggle, have got in common.
You're right, Ron. Is there anything you'd like to try from their world, perhaps?

You're asking a Weasley if there's food to try? Are you having a laugh? I'd try one of those bananas for sure, maybe compare it to a Pumpkin Pasty. But honestly, I'd like to get in there, see the people, learn how it all works. Who knows, could give me an idea for a Muggle side of Weasleys’ Wizard Wheezes!
That sounds like an exciting adventure, Ron. Maybe we can learn a spell to turn a Gurdyroot into a banana?

Ha! Hermione would have a fit if she heard you suggesting botched transfiguration like that. But I reckon it'd be worth a try – as long as it doesn't end up screaming like those Mandrakes. Alright, let's give this wild idea a go then... just be ready to run if it starts sprouting legs or something.
Look at this, Ron! We've stumbled upon a trio of teddy bears and a bottle of wine. What do you think they're up to?
Blimey, it's like they're having their own little party, isn't it? Maybe it's a celebration for a stuffed animals' quidditch match!
A stuffed animals' quidditch match? Now that's a funny image. Do you think they're discussing strategies or celebrating a win?
Definitely celebrating a win. Look at the one in the middle—he’s got that Fred and George victorious smirk. And the bottle of Merlot? Must've been a fancy occasion, perhaps the Teddy Cup Finals!
The Teddy Cup Finals, I love it! And the bear on the left looks a bit tipsy, don't you think?
Right you are. Looks like someone's had a bit too much of the old grape juice. Reminds me of a certain someone's behavior at the Yule Ball... not naming any names.
I wonder what they would toast to. Any ideas?
Knowing teddy bears? Probably to friendship and snug cuddles. Although if it were me, I'd raise a glass to a day without any rogue bludgers or homework from Snape.
Ha! I'm sure they'd appreciate a day without rogue bludgers. And how about the one on the right, seems quite cozy in his jumper.
Yeah, that jumper gives me strong vibes of Mum's hand-knits. Cozy as can be. Makes me miss The Burrow a little, to be honest.
I can imagine. So, do you think these little guys would be Gryffindors, just like you?
With their sense of camaraderie? I'd bet my last Chocolate Frog card on it. Gryffindor teddies, through and through.
I think you're right. They've surely got that brave look about them, ready to face any adventure—or maybe any bedtime story—with courage and a smile.
And a full bottle of Merlot, apparently! Care for a pretend toast before we head off?
Absolutely, Ron. To brave teddy bears and timeless friendships.
To brave teddy bears and timeless friendships. And let's nip out before they ask us to clean up.
Wow, Ron, look at this! Where do you reckon we are?
Blimey, I'm not sure, but that looks like one brilliant bit of craftsmanship right there. Bet it wasn't made by gnomes, heh.
It's so intricate and detailed, isn't it? Kind of reminds me of something you might find in Diagon Alley, but more Muggle-like.

Yeah, you're right! It's like something straight out of Flourish and Blotts window display, except it's not magic — I mean, not wizard magic anyway. Muggles can be pretty clever with their hands, can't they?
Definitely! Do you think this is a clock tower of some sort? It’s hard to tell without any pointers or clock hands.

Well, if that's a clock, I reckon it's broken, or maybe it's one of those arty things, like a sculpture. My dad would go barmy over this; he loves Muggle stuff. Reckon he'd talk their ears off about it at the dinner table.

It does seem like an art piece, you're right. And the way the shadows play on it — it's almost enchanting. Could you imagine if it was enchanted? What kind of spell would you use on a clock tower like that?

Enchanting? Merlin's beard, if we had something like that at Hogwarts, it would probably tell us more than just the time. Maybe cast a Time-Turner spell so we could nip back and avoid Snape's detentions, ha!
That would be useful! Or what if it could display messages like the Patronus charm, but instead of a whisper, it spells out notes in mid-air?

Wicked idea! That way, Hermione wouldn't have to scold me about missing study sessions because the tower would just flash "Ron, library, now!" across the sky. Or maybe "Ron, don't forget your potions homework." Though I'd rather not be reminded of that.
Haha, it does sound like something Hermione would appreciate. What an incredible sight that would be, Ron. I'm glad we stumbled upon it today, even if we're not quite sure what it's really for.
Me too. Being with Muggles isn't so bad, especially when they've got stuff like this. Makes you think we could use a bit of Muggle ingenuity at The Burrow.
Maybe you'll find a way to blend the Muggle craftsmanship with a touch of magic from the wizarding world.
Now that’s an idea. Dad would be over the moon... and maybe Mum would finally let him have that Muggle car part he’s been eyeing if it's part of a bigger magical project, ha!
Hey Ron, look at this! We've traveled in time and space, and now we're standing next to this road sign that says "ONE LANE." What do you think it means in this context?

Blimey, I reckon it means there's only one lane on this stretch of road for the cars to use. It’s like the one-lane bridge near Ottery St Catchpole, but without the charm of being surrounded by fields and the Burrow's orchard.
And what about those bicycles and that scooter? How do they fit into this road system?

Well, it looks a bit dodgy to me. Wizards don't need these sorts of complications with Apparition and broomsticks. But I'd say muggles would have to be extra careful not to run into each other, wouldn’t they? Just like playing Quidditch but everyone's on the ground and there's no Quaffle in sight.
Do you think that road sign would make a difference in the wizarding world? Would it be useful at all?

Are you having a laugh? In the wizarding world, we'd probably have a sign that moved and shouted warnings if you were going the wrong way or too fast. Maybe even with a spell to slow you down. Mum would love that, always worried about us getting into mischief.
It's interesting to see the contrast between muggle road rules and the free-spirited nature of magical transportation. Things are much more structured here, huh?

Absolutely. But, you know, there's structure in magic too, isn't there? Spells and potions all have rules. Still, I'd take a broomstick over a traffic jam any day. No blasted "ONE LANE" nonsense up in the air!
Imagine having a sign in the sky directing dragon traffic or something like that.

Dragon traffic? Haha, that’s one for Charlie, he’d have a field day. Although, I reckon dragons don't take kindly to being told where to fly. Can you imagine trying to install a sign like that? "Oi, Norbert, mind swinging left at the next cloud?" You’d be dragon toast before you even finished the sentence.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts, Ron. It's been quite enlightening and entertaining.
No problem! Always happy to share a bit of wizard insight on these muggle curiosities. Just don't ask me to explain plumbing to you – now that is a system that could use some magic.
Look at this, Ron! We've traveled back in time! What do you make of this scene?
Blimey, this is brilliant! It's like stepping into a history book, innit? No moving pictures or anything!
Yes, it's quite different from our time. What do you think people would have been doing on a day like this?
Well, I reckon those blokes over there might be heading to work or something. And look at that, there's a carriage without any thestrals or hippogriffs to pull it!
It's funny you mention work; do you see anything familiar that might tell us what kind of jobs they had?
Hmm, tricky that, without magic to give it away. But those buildings look proper fancy; maybe some of them are shopkeepers or business owners?
They could be. Notice anything unusual in the image that you don't often see in our time?

Everything's unusual to me here. The clothes are a dead giveaway—so many layers! And is that a hat on everyone's head? Don't think I'd fancy wearing one of those every day. There's no sign of a single robe, though. Not a one. How bizarre!
Indeed! They're quite different from wizarding robes. What about transportation? How does it compare to wizarding ways of getting around?
Well, if I had to choose, I'd pick a broom over that carriage any day. It's all so... slow, isn't it? Can't apparate, no Floo network—it's like everyone's stuck in first gear!
That's true. They certainly didn't have the convenience of magical transportation. What would you say you'd miss the most from our time if you lived in this era?

Honestly? I'd miss a good game of Quidditch the most. Can't imagine this lot knows what a Quaffle is, much less a Snitch. And let's not even start on the food – I'd trade all the fancy hats in the world for Mum's homemade treacle tart.
Ron, check this out! We're not in Hogwarts anymore, that's for sure. What do you think that sign says?
Blimey, it looks like it's got some sort of strange runes on it. But wait, that's just another language, isn't it? "Þjóðminjasafn" – must be some sort of spell... or maybe not.
It actually says "National museum" in Icelandic. It's the language spoken in Iceland. Any idea what a national museum might hold?

Icelandic, eh? Mum and Dad always wanted to take us on a holiday abroad, never managed it though. I reckon a national museum's got all sorts of historical knick-knacks, maybe even some magical artifacts. Like a muggle version of the Department of Mysteries, but less... well, mysterious.
Exactly! It collects and preserves the country's history. What sort of artifacts do wizards have that could be in a museum like this?

Well, you've got your usual witch and wizarding heirlooms, haven't you? Stuff like the Sword of Gryffindor or even Helga Hufflepuff's Cup, before, you know, it got Horcrux-ed. But most wizard stuff would probably have enchantments to keep muggles from getting too nosy.
Speaking of nosy, there's someone standing under the sign. What do you think he's looking at?

Probably using one of those muggle contraptions, a camera or something. Colin Creevey used to babble on about those. Or maybe he's lost. That street doesn't look like Diagon Alley, where people usually know where they're going. No shops selling cauldrons or brooms.
You've got a point. Now that we're looking at mundane streets, don't you find it a bit peaceful compared to the chaos of the wizarding world sometimes?

I suppose. It's different, quieter, no one's looking over their shoulder for Death Eaters or waiting for a Bludger to come their way. But a bit too quiet for my taste. I'd miss the magical mess. And where's the fun without a little chaos, right?
That's a very Ron answer! Thanks for your thoughts on this, and it was quite an experience traveling through time and space with you to see this.

Anytime! Not that I entirely understand how we got here, time travel's messy enough when it's just hours we're talking about. Let's hope Hermione doesn't find out, or she'll have us writing essays on the ethics of it for a month.
Wow, look at this, Ron! What do you make of these bright blurry lines and those red lights against the dark?

Blimey, that's a bit dizzying, isn't it? Kind of like a broomstick's got out of control during a storm. But those red lights—I reckon they look like the sparks from my brothers' Wildfire Whiz-bangs. Only less explosive, thankfully.
It looks like traffic lights, don't you think? With streaking headlights of Muggle cars zooming past.
Right, traffic lights! Dad would go barmy over this, he loves all that Muggle stuff. But Muggle cars—I dunno, they always look so sluggish to me. These ones have got some speed though, haven't they?
They sure do. Can you imagine trying to navigate through this on a broom?

Ha! It'd take a fair bit of fancy flying, wouldn't it? Though it's nothing compared to the Quidditch pitch. Still, I'd keep my Invisibility Booster handy; I don't fancy becoming a splat on some Muggle's windscreen.
How do you suppose they manage without magic? Everything seems so hectic.

Well, Hermione always says it's about innovation—Muggles finding their own way to get by without spells and potions. I reckon it's impressive, in a way. But, give me a wand and a broom over this traffic any day.
Me too, Ron. It's fascinating how they all follow these lights and manage not to crash into each other without any magical assistance.
I know! It's sort of like watching a really well-coordinated, uh, what's the word... ballet? Yeah, that's it. Except with cars instead of dancers. And definitely no tutus.
A car ballet... now that's an image! Thanks, Ron, for your unique perspective on Muggle traffic. It certainly adds a bit of magic to the view.
Anytime! Always happy to share a bit of Weasley wisdom. Just don't ask me to drive one of those things—I'm sticking to apparition and Floo powder, thanks very much.

Hey Ron, take a look at this. We've somehow ended up in the Muggle world and there are these two things with screens. They look similar to the television screens in the Dursleys’ house, but these seem different. What do you think they are?
Blimey, it's a couple of those computer things, isn't it? Dad's always going on about all the fascinating Muggle artefacts he's come across. He'd probably be over the moon to poke around at these.
Yes, they are computers! Muggles use them for all sorts of things like work, communication, entertainment... They are quite versatile. Can you guess what they might be doing with them?

Well, I reckon one looks like it's got some sort of code on it – my dad mentioned how Muggles have a whole language for these contraptions. And the other one, maybe sending an owl... without the owl? Weird lot, Muggles.
That's a good guess! The code is probably for programming, which is how Muggles tell the computer what to do, and you're right about the communication part, except they call it emailing.
Emailing, eh? Sounds boring. I reckon a good old-fashioned owl has much more character. And you don't need to plug an owl into the wall to make it go.
That's true! Owls definitely have their charm. See that little device next to the computers? That's called a mouse. It's what they use to interact with what's on the screen.
A mouse? That little thing? It doesn't look anything like a mouse. No tail or beady eyes or anything. And how on earth does it interact with the screen? Magic?

It's not literal magic, but Muggles might call it a technological marvel. By moving the mouse, you can navigate a little arrow on the screen to tell the computer what you want to do. No spells necessary.
Huh, technological marvel, you say? Seems like a whole lot of effort when a scrap of parchment and a quick "Accio" does the trick. But I've got to admit, it's fascinating – in a Muggle-y way.
Hey Ron, check this out! What do you make of that odd license plate on the lorry? Looks almost like it could be a spell or something, doesn't it? "F8 246 anion" What do you think that could mean?

Blimey, that's a bit of a stretch, isn't it? Though I reckon 'F8' could seem like 'fate' if you squint a bit – kind of like how 'alohomora' sounds like 'aloe vera' to Muggles. As for 'anion,' well, that's a Muggle chemistry term, not much to do with spells. Maybe it's just a random jumble of letters and numbers, you know.
Haha, fair enough. But what about the date at the bottom? "2009 08 02." Could it be some significant historical event in the muggle world?

Well, if we were in the Muggle Studies class, maybe Hermione would have some insight with all her extra reading. But off the top of my head, I can't figure it. I mean, 2009 was after the Battle of Hogwarts, so we were a bit busy with... other things. Maybe it's just when the lorry was made or something equally mundane.
True, Hermione would probably know. There's a bag hanging off the side, too—any wild guesses about what might be in it?

Looks like someone’s been shopping at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes and forgot to shrink their purchases properly before sneaking them back home – just joking, of course. Honestly, it could be anything; tools, lunch, a spare broomstick... though I doubt that last one. Muggles and their vehicles, they've got all sorts of compartments and add-ons.

A spare broomstick for a truck – now that's funny! How do you suppose this scene fits into the bigger picture? Just a regular day in the muggle world where they're concerned with schedules and deliveries?

Ordinary for Muggles, perhaps, but it’s sort of fascinating, isn’t it? They've got their own kind of magic – all these gadgets and machines that zoom around. It makes me appreciate how different our worlds are, even though they overlap sometimes. Just a normal day for them, I s'pose, like us on our brooms or apparating—everyone's got their way of moving through life.
Definitely, each world has its unique charm. Thanks for sharing your thoughts, Ron!

No problem! It’s not like we’re decoding the secrets of the universe, but taking a peek into the Muggle way of life is always an interesting detour, isn't it? Always makes me hungry though... speaking of which, you haven't seen a Cauldron Cake lying around, have you?
Ron, look at this! People are surfing, but not on an ocean wave—it's a river! Have you ever seen anything like this in the wizarding world?

Blimey, that's mental! They're on a tiny bit of water, but surfing like they're facing a Hippogriff-sized wave. In the wizarding world, we've got similar things, like enchanted carpets or brooms, but using natural water like this? It's bonkers, but brilliant!
I wonder how they manage to stay on the wave without being swept away. Any ideas?

It's got to be a bit like balancing on a broom, hasn't it? You've got to keep your center of gravity just right, or you'll end up with more than a wet bottom. And look at them all lined up – it's like queuing for a Quidditch tryout, but with wetsuits and boards.
It's fascinating, really. Do you think this requires the same kind of skill as playing wizard's chess?

Well, I reckon it's all about strategy and anticipation, isn't it? You've got to read the wave, just like you've got to read your opponent's mind in a game of chess. But here, you need nimble feet as well as a sharp brain—can't say my chess pieces ever required me to stay afloat!
Do you think you would ever give it a try?

You're a little scary sometimes, you know that? Fancying me on a surfboard, haha! But I guess, if Harry and Hermione were game, I might give it a go. Couldn't let them show me up, could I? After all, I did defeat that chess set in my first year. How much harder could this be?
I'm sure you'd be great at it! This seems like a fun Muggle sport. I'm surprised it's not more common.

Well, the Muggles do come up with some cracking ideas. Dad would be over the moon to see this—he's nuts about Muggle stuff. Maybe I'll bring him along, give him a board and see how he manages not to sink straight to the bottom like a blast-ended skrewt!
That would be quite the sight! Thanks for sharing this moment with me, Ron.

Anytime! It's been a right laugh. And if you ever fancy surfing the great lake at Hogwarts, count me out. I'll stick to dry land and a good game of chess. But you go on—I’ll cheer you on from the shore with a sandwich or something. Can't miss out on watching the fun, can I?
Definitely not. It wouldn't be the same without your commentary, Ron.
Cheers to that! Now, let's find a place to warm up. All this water's made me feel colder than a Dementor's handshake. And I reckon I could eat a hippogriff. I'm starved!
Look at this image, Ron! Have you ever seen creatures like these up close in the wizarding world?

Blimey, those are elephants! They're sorta like the Muggle version of a Hippogriff, just without the wings, aren’t they? I've read about them in Muggle Studies. Large and in charge they are, but no match for a Hungarian Horntail, I reckon.
They seem so majestic and calm, don't they? What do you think life would be like for a wizard among them?

Majestic and calm, until you nick their peanuts, I suppose. A wizard among them would have an easier time than a Muggle, I'd bet. A quick 'Alohomora' could solve any lock if they got poached, and a 'Scourgify' to keep 'em clean without a fuss. Plus, they could Apparate water right over if they got thirsty.
Do you think these elephants would exist in the Forbidden Forest at Hogwarts?

Are you taking the Mickey? Forbidden Forest is creepy enough with acromantulas and thestrals. Can you imagine stumbling upon one of these after dark? You’d have Fred and George setting up a safari tour right next to Aragog's old haunt! But no, they wouldn't survive long amongst the centaurs and other magical beasts there.
How would your family react to seeing these elephants?

Mum would probably try to knit 'em all a jumper each, big as the house, though I'm not sure how she’d get them to try it on. Dad would lose his marbles, ask them a million questions about being a Muggle animal. Ginny might want to ride one, George would surely figure out some way to involve them in a new product line, and Percy... Well, Percy'd probably draft a formal complaint about the improbability of their existence in the English countryside.
It could be a challenge to have an elephant at The Burrow, huh?

A challenge? It’d be a right nightmare! You thought the garden gnomes were bad? Wait till there's an elephant in the garden! It would be like having Grawp for a tea party every day, but without the conversation.
I wonder how magic could help in protecting these creatures from poachers.

Well, aside from casting a few ‘Protego’ around their territory, I suppose wizards could use 'Muggle-Repelling Charms' to keep poachers away! For tougher cases, 'Disillusionment Charms' could make 'em blend right into the surroundings, or, if worst comes to worst, 'Portkeys' to zap them away from danger! But whatever the spell, it’s important to keep 'em safe. They're just brilliant, aren’t they?
They are, Ron. Thanks for sharing your thoughts! It's fascinating to think about the magical possibilities.
No problem! Always happy to talk about animals, magical or not. Just don’t get Hagrid started, or we’ll be here all day listening to his plans for an elephant sanctuary next to his hut!
Wow, take a look at that, Ron! I've never seen so many different kinds of treats in one place. What do you make of this?
Blimey, that's a brilliant sight! It’s like a feast for the eyes... and the stomach! I reckon they've got every flavor you could dream of.
Do you have a favorite among these? I'm tempted to try one of those that look like a crossover between a croissant and a doughnut.

Those? They're called cronuts! Fred and George mentioned them once. Said they're the next best thing to a box of Skiving Snackboxes. I’d fancy one of those chocolate ones right there. After all, everything’s better with chocolate, isn’t it?
Absolutely! And what about those powdered ones, any thoughts on those?

Well, they remind me a bit of cauldron cakes dusted with powdered moonstone, except, I'm betting they're sweeter and won't turn you into a canary. Reckon I could munch on those all day and not get bored.
It's a bit overwhelming with all the choices, isn't it? I wonder how they make so many varieties.
It must be some sort of Muggle magic, I suppose. Hermione would say it's all about baking science, but I'd rather not think about the how and just enjoy the what, you know?
Ron, you always know how to put things into perspective. Which one would you try first?

I'd go for that mountain of sugar ones, straight in the middle. Look how the sugar glistens—a bit like fresh snow over Hogsmeade, but the taste must be loads better. The only problem is knowing where to start!
I think I'll join you on that. Let's dig in before they all vanish faster than a Disappearing Cabinet.
Ha! Lead the way. And hey, if we can't decide, why not just try a bit of each? That's the Ron Weasley way – the more, the merrier!
Wow, take a look at this! I've never seen a dish like this before. What do you make of it, Ron? It looks quite hearty, doesn't it?
Blimey, that does look fit for a feast at The Burrow, doesn't it? It's making my mouth water just looking at it. Do you reckon there's any beef in there? Mum makes a mean beef stew.
I think so, and there seem to be a lot of vegetables too. Probably a mix of everything you'd want for a proper meal. And look at that sauce!
You're telling me. That sauce looks like it has a kick to it. Fred and George would drop a couple of their Peruvian Instant Darkness Powders to sneak seconds without being seen, the nifflers.
Haha, I bet they would. Do you think you'd learn to make this at Hogwarts in a Potions class, or would it be more of a Molly Weasley specialty?

Potions? Snape would have my head if I turned up with a cauldron full of this. No, this is straight out of Mum's wheelhouse. Cooking's a bit like potions, except you get to eat the results. And I'm all for that.
Speaking of which, do you miss the feasts at Hogwarts? They always seemed so magical with the dishes appearing out of nowhere.
Miss them? Every single day. The Great Hall was brilliant. All the food you could eat, just appearing there! And I didn't even have to duel a troll to get to it. Though I would, for a plate of this.
I could see why! Last question, Ron. If you had to share this dish with one person, who would it be?

Just one? That's tougher than a N.E.W.T. exam. But I'd have to say Hermione, wouldn't I? She'd probably figure out how to replicate it with magic, and then I could eat it whenever I wanted. Smart, that one.
Very smart indeed. Well, thanks for joining me on this time-travel excursion, Ron. This has been quite the experience, looking at foods of the past with you.
Anytime. It's been a blast. Now, if only we could actually have a taste of it! Accio spoon! ...No, nothing's happening. Guess magic doesn't work on images, after all.
I guess we'll have to use our imaginations for now.

Always the hardest part. But I've got plenty of practice at that, haven't I? Now, let's get back before someone notices we're gone. Wouldn't want to miss supper at the Burrow, especially if Mum's making anything half as good as this.
Look at this, Ron! Have you ever seen anything like it? What do you think happened here?

Blimey, that's a bit of a mess, isn't it? It looks like someone's cast a Cluttering Charm, though I reckon it's just muggle untidiness. Fred and George’s room looked a bit like this after their experiments.
Seems like someone was in a hurry, doesn't it? Do you think they were looking for something?

Could be, or maybe they’ve got a niffler stashed away in there; they tend to toss everything upside down. Mind you, it could just be someone rushing off to work or school, Mum yells the same thing about Ginny and me all the time.
And what about the dog? He seems so calm amidst the chaos.

I wouldn't be surprised if he's the culprit behind half this mess - animals can cause quite a ruckus. Though in the Wizarding World, it could've been a misbehaving magical creature. Ever heard of a Crup? They look just like dogs but with a forked tail.
Do you think there's anything valuable hidden in that room? Something worth using a revealing spell for?

Doubt it. It’s more likely to find a lost sock than anything of value in there. Although, you never know — could be a hidden stash of Chocolate Frog cards. I wouldn’t mind a summoning charm to get those.
With your experience with magical creatures, do you think a pet could be trained to tidy up rooms?
A house-elf can, definitely. But a regular pet? That would take some serious training, and even then, I’d bet my Chocolate Frog cards they'd get distracted by a treat or a good snuggle.
I can't help but wonder, if this was a scene from the Wizarding World - how would you go about investigating it?

First, check for hexes and jinxes, then I’d ask Hermione what spell to use. She’s brilliant at this sort of thing. But really, it's probably just an everyday mess, nothing a Scourgify wouldn't sort out in a heartbeat.
Imagine if this room belonged to someone at Hogwarts, who do you think it would be?
That's an easy one. It screams Seamus Finnigan — his things are always a smidge explosive, if you know what I mean. But without the scorch marks, you can tell there's not been any magical mishaps.
It’s been fun speculating about this with you, Ron. Before we leave, what would you take with you from this room as a memento?
Maybe that cosy-looking blanket on the bed — reminds me of the ones at The Burrow. Warm and comforting, you know? Just the thing after a long day of... well, doing Ron Weasley sorts of things.
Look at this, Ron! Ever seen something like that before?
Blimey, that's not something you'd find at the lake by the Burrow, that's for sure. Looks like muggle surfing, doesn't it? Except, small... what do they call it? Bodyboarding, maybe?
Yes, it's bodyboarding! Have you ever tried a Muggle sport like this?
Me? On a tiny plank in the water, waiting to be gulped down by a grindylow? No thanks. I reckon I'll stick to Quidditch. But I have to admit, it looks like a right laugh.
Would you ever consider giving it a go if you had the chance?

Well, I suppose if Harry and Hermione were up for it, I'd have a go. You won't catch me diving in first though, I'll tell you that. And I'm not great with big bodies of water... remember the second task?
How do you think this compares to flying on a broomstick?

Flying's a whole different kettle of kneazles. Up in the air, there's a freedom to it, isn't there? With this, you're sort of at the mercy of the waves. Still, it's the same sort of thrill, I guess. The rush and all.
What do you think Hermione would say about this?

Hermione? She'd probably lecture us on the history of Muggle water sports and the importance of proper safety charms... I mean, techniques. But deep down, I reckon she'd fancy trying it too, just for the experience.
Let's say you were out there on the waves, and a rogue bludger came at you. What would you do?

A rogue bludger? While bodyboarding? I'd probably... well, first I'd wonder who let it out of the chest. Then I'd do my best to dodge it, but let's be honest, on the water I'd probably be as useful as a Chocolate Frog card's defensive spells. I'll leave the bludgers to Quidditch, thanks.
This photograph looks like it's from a long time ago, don't you think? The clothes they're wearing seem pretty old-fashioned.

Blimey, you're right. The jumpers look a bit like the ones my mum knits for me every Christmas – except these are even more old-school. Do you reckon they had wizard photographers back then, or is this Muggle work?
It might be Muggle work; photography was a big thing for documenting life in the past. Look at their expressions, Ron; none of the children are smiling. Why do you think that is?

Well, I remember reading in 'A History of Magic' that back in the day, it took ages for a photo to be taken, so it was hard to hold a smile that long. Could've been they were just tired of waiting. Or maybe they'd rather be off playing Hippogriff than sitting still for a photo.
There's that sense of humor. You're probably right. And look how close they're sitting to each other. What do you make of that?

They look squished together like sardines in a tin! Maybe the photographer had one of those really naff cameras that could only capture a small bit in front of it. Or... perhaps they were just trying to keep warm?
That makes sense, given their heavy clothes. And the black and white... gives it a sort of timeless feel, don't you think?

Absolutely. It's like when Dad tries to explain how things were when he was young. Everything seems so different but, at the same time, some things never change. Like family, or sitting for photos. Even in the wizarding world, some things are just... universal, I suppose.
Couldn't agree more, Ron. It's fascinating to think about how much has changed but what remains the same at its core. Thanks for sharing your thoughts!
No problem. It's kind of nice, really. Reminds me of the photographs at home, even if ours do move and all. Now, shall we head back before Hermione thinks we've been lost in time?
Wow, check this out, Ron! Ever seen a pizza before?
Pizza? Yeah, I've heard of it. Hermione mentioned it a few times, says it's a popular Muggle dish. Looks like the kind of thing that'd go fast at the Weasley dinner table.
It’s got this delicious-looking crust and toppings. What do you think those green leaves are?

Not sure exactly, but they look a bit like the leaves from the Gillyweed plant. Only, I reckon these ones won't make you grow gills and webbed feet. They're probably just some herb. Mum uses something like that in her stews sometimes.
That’s basil, Ron. It’s a herb used a lot in Italian cooking.
Basil, right. I'll have to remember that. Seems to give off a nice smell too. Do you reckon it's as filling as a good plate of mum's corned beef?
Well, it’s not the same, but it can be quite satisfying. See the cheese there? That’s mozzarella.
Mozzarella? Blimey, Muggles have some funny names for their cheeses. Back home it's just cheddar, and it doesn't melt all stringy like that. Looks good, though. I'm getting hungry just eyeballing it.
Haha, I bet. Look at the crust, it's got some char on the edges – that's usually a sign of a proper wood-fired oven.
Really? I'd say it looks like they ought to clean out their fireplace, but I reckon it adds a bit of flavor? Seems like Muggles know a thing or two about cooking after all, even without magic.
Absolutely. And this style is called Neapolitan—it’s from Naples in Italy. They take their pizza very seriously there.
Naples, Italy, huh? Maybe I'll take Hermione on a food tour there sometime—after all, if there's something I've learned, it's that trying new foods is almost as fun as a good Quidditch match.
That’s the spirit, Ron! I think you’d enjoy the adventure, maybe even learn a couple of tricks to bring back to The Burrow.

Yeah, that'd be brilliant. I can just see the look on Mum's face if I conjured up a pizza like this for dinner. Thanks for the virtual food tour! Now, how about we find a place where I can actually eat one of these marvelous creations?
Look at this, Ron! It's a baby eating a chocolate doughnut. Have you ever seen anything so muggle and adorable?
Blimey, that's one messy way to eat! It's like he's gone and put a Confounding Charm on that doughnut – doesn't have a clue how to handle it, does he?
I think that's just the way little kids eat. But speaking of doughnuts, have you ever had one?

Can't say I have, not a proper one like that. Mostly pumpkin pasties and cauldron cakes back at Hogwarts, right? I wouldn't mind trying it though – it looks like it could give a Chocolate Frog a run for its Galleons!
I'm sure you'd love it. They come in all sorts of flavors. What do you think this little tyke is thinking right now?
Well, judging by the look on his face, probably something like 'Accio more doughnuts!' I reckon if babies could do magic, there'd be no stopping the treats.
Magic would certainly make snack time interesting. Do you think the magical world has anything similar to this kind of muggle messiness?
