You've never seen the Great Hall after a feast, then? It's like a herd of Nifflers went through searching for shiny things. Food everywhere! Though, honestly, house-elves tidy up quicker than you can say 'Scourgify!'
That sounds quite efficient. Too bad muggles don't have house-elves to clean up after a mess like this, huh?

Yeah, I've always thought you lot could use a bit of help in the cleaning department. Just think of the time you'd save. Could spend it learning spells instead of scrubbing floors. Or, you know, finding more ways to get doughnut icing in your hair.
Maybe that's just a special skill we non-magical folk have, achieving maximum mess with minimum effort!

Sounds about right. But, you've got to admit, it makes for a good laugh. And speaking of laughs, George would probably invent something to make the mess bigger, not clean it up. For 'comic effect' and all that.
I can only imagine. It'd make for quite the memorable afternoon tea at The Burrow, wouldn't it?
More like unforgettable. Mum would go spare though, doughnut jam on her clean floors? I'd rather face a Hungarian Horntail than deal with that aftermath.
Hey Ron, check out this photo from my time and space travel. It's a young kid playing baseball, or well, attempting to. What do you think?
Blimey, baseball? That's like the American version of cricket, isn't it? But where's the bludger and the bats... Oh wait, the bat's right there. I reckon it’s all off-brand Quidditch gear!
Yeah, something like that. No bludgers though, just one ball. And the kid, see how focused he is? It’s all about hitting the ball as hard as you can.

Right, like a Beater. Only there's no flying. And he's not trying to knock anyone off a broom. Seems a bit less dangerous, doesn't it? But I’ve got to admit, the determination on his face is brilliant. Practically Gryffindor-level bravery facing that, erm, "pitch" is it?
Exactly! A pitch. He stands there waiting for it and swings when it's time. There’s a lot of skill involved actually.

Skill, eh? Well, I'd like to see them try that with a Quaffle zooming towards them a hundred miles an hour. But I suppose it takes some courage to stand in front of a speedy ball like that. It's all in the wrist action, perhaps? I used a bit of that technique when I played Keeper.
Yeah, you’re catching on! So, imagine coaching this kid—what kind of advice would you give him from your Quidditch experience?

Well, first off, keep your eye on the ball – or the Snitch, whatever's being hurled at you. Stay light on your feet, ready to move. And, of course, don't let the Slytherin team get in your head. It's all mental, isn't it?
That's some solid advice! And don't you find it interesting how Muggles have their own versions of sports, without any magic involved?

It's mental how Muggles manage without a bit of magic. But I've always said, there’s magic of sorts in the stuff they do. Just look at this little chap, ready to swing like he's going for the World Cup final. He doesn't need a wand—a bat's good enough. And that's sort of magical itself, wouldn't you say?
I would, Ron. You’ve got a way of seeing the magic in everything. Makes me think you’d have been a great Muggle Studies teacher.

Ha! Can you imagine? Ronald Weasley, Professor of Muggle Studies... My brothers would never let me hear the end of it. But I reckon I’d fancy giving it a go. After all, Muggles are endlessly fascinating, aren’t they? Just like this plucky little bloke here.
This place looks fascinating, doesn't it? The architecture is quite majestic with that grand clock tower. I wonder what the significance of this building could be.

Yeah, it does seem impressive, doesn't it? Reminds me a bit of Hogwarts with all the spires and towers, though nothing's quite like the castle. And the clock tower... well, it's not as magical as the one we've got, but maybe it's important to the Muggles?
I'm curious about what this place might be used for in the Muggle world. Any ideas on how we could find out?

Well, Hermione would probably say we should pop into the local library and have a look in some history books, but I reckon we could just ask one of the Muggles walking around. They look like they're heading somewhere – maybe inside.
That clock, though, I can't help but be drawn to it. It's almost like it's bearing witness to countless events. Do you think if that clock could talk, what tales it would tell?

Blimey, yeah, I bet it would have stories. Like the Whomping Willow, only without the thrashing, obviously. It'd tell you when it was built, all the comings and goings, and the faces it's seen day in and day out. Clocks are a bit like keepers of time, aren't they?
It's true. By the way, did you notice the design around the clock face? It seems to stand out.

I see what you mean – sort of fancy and intricate-like, right? Wizards use runes and symbols for all sorts of magical purposes, but I wonder what Muggles try to convey with those decorations. Maybe it's just to look nice, or perhaps it's meaningful, like crests and stuff. Makes you think, doesn't it?
Definitely, Ron. And look at the sky's colors behind the tower. It's rather picturesque. Don't you think it adds a dramatic backdrop to the building?

For sure. If I were good at drawing, I'd like to capture that sort of thing. Mum always says there's beauty in the everyday, and that sky – the way it frames the building – is exactly what she's on about. It's peaceful, in a way, but also a bit thrilling. Like waiting for a Quidditch match to start.
I couldn't agree more. It's pretty wonderful to just stand here and take it all in with you, Ron. Thanks for sharing this moment.
No worries, it's been a decent change of pace. No dark wizards or giant spiders here, just a good old Muggle building and some nice scenery. It's the simple things sometimes, isn't it?
Hey Ron, check this out. Ever seen anything like this in the wizarding world?
Blimey, what's that Muggle contraption with all the little blokes in it?
That's a television, Ron. It's kind of like the moving pictures in the Daily Prophet, but for Muggles.
And those people stuck inside... are they enchanted?
Nope, they're virtual athletes from a video game. Think of it as a charmed chessboard where the figures move and play sports instead of battling.
A charmed chessboard that plays Quidditch would be brilliant! Mum would never get me to leave the living room.
Haha, yeah, I can imagine. Muggle kids love to play these games. See how focused the kid is on playing?
He's got the concentration of a Seeker during the final match of the Quidditch Cup!
Exactly! And sometimes players get as competitive as if they're in a real sporting match.
Cor, that's mental! In our world, we'd just fly around and actually hit a Bludger or two.
I bet you would, Ron. But for people who can't fly on brooms, this is the next best thing.
Can't fly on brooms? That's the saddest thing I've heard. Everyone should have the chance to feel the wind in their hair, zooming above the ground.
Maybe one day with enough Muggle advancements. But hey, do you want to give the game a try?
Well then, let's fire up this game, and I'll show you the Weasley way on the pitch — virtual or not!
Prepare to be amazed, Ron. And just a heads up, there's no Felix Felicis to help you here.
Don't need it. You'll see, my reflexes are as sharp as a sword. Let's do this! But, er… you might want to give me a quick rundown on how it works first.
Hey Ron, check this out! I traveled back in time and found this brilliant image of an elephant having a bath. What do you reckon they're thinking?
Blimey, that's a massive creature! It's like the hippogriffs back at Hogwarts, except with no wings. And that's some serious water power; reckon it's having the time of its life!
Yeah, it looks quite happy, doesn't it? Have you ever seen an elephant in person before?

Nah, never had the chance to see one up close like this. The closest I've seen is a picture in one of Hermione's Muggle books. Wouldn't mind getting an audience with this giant, though. Looks friendly enough.
What would you say to it if you could talk to animals?
Well, if we're imagining, I'd tell it, "You’ve got an impressive way of showering there! Care to teach me that spell?" though it's not really using magic, is it? Just having a good splash.
I think it would laugh if it understood you. With the heat nowadays, we could all use a nice cool bath like that, right?
You're telling me! After Quidditch practice, a soak like this would be ace. Nothing like cooling off after a long day. Just hope it doesn't spray me like that, I'd be soaked through in seconds!
Speaking of soaking, ever been caught in rain during Quidditch?
Oh yeah, loads of times. Feels like you're being pelted by a hundred Bludgers at once. But this elephant, he makes it look like a bit of water's nothing to worry about. I'm a tad envious, actually.
Maybe it's because they're so big, the water's just like a gentle massage to them.
That does make sense. Like those little magical creatures—Bowtruckles—tiny to us, but the world's a whole different scale to them.
True! Scale really changes perspectives. Last question, Ron: If you could be any magical creature, what would you be?
That's a tough one. Probably a dragon. They're terrifying, but imagine flying without a broom, breathing fire, being nearly invincible. Yeah, a dragon for sure. How about you?
Maybe something that could swim like this elephant, but magical... a Merperson, perhaps?
Good choice! Bit slimy for my taste, but the underwater world's fascinating. Just watch out for those Grindylows, they're nastier than they look.
I'll keep that in mind! Thanks for chatting, Ron.
Anytime! Now, let's see if we can't find that elephant a nice-sized pool at Hogwarts; I reckon Hagrid would love that!
Whoa, Ron, check this out! Ever seen anything like this in the wizarding world?
Blimey, that’s not something you see every day, is it? That's what Muggles call an 'airplane,' right? I’ve heard Dad go on about those. They use them to fly without magic!
Actually, this one's a bit special – it's a historic warplane. It's called a P-51 Mustang, from World War II. Amazing, isn't it?

A warplane? You know, it reminds me a bit of a broom, in a sense... only much larger, and I reckon a lot noisier. Would’ve been useful during the Battle of Hogwarts, I bet—give those Death Eaters something to think twice about!
It was essential during the war, for sure. They played a huge role in air combat. What were the main flying contraptions used in wizard battles?
Well, we use brooms mostly. There’s nothing like speeding through the air on a Nimbus or a Firebolt. But then, you’ve got things like thestrals and hippogriffs if you’re not fussed about stealth.
Do you think a wizard could fly one of these without knowing how to pilot it, using magic perhaps?

Ha! You’d have a better chance of taming a Hungarian Horntail, I reckon. But, hypothetically, if a wizard was good at Muggle Studies... maybe a Confundus Charm to make the plane think it was being piloted properly? Or a good old Levitation Charm in a pinch, but it’d be a beast to control.
The Confundus Charm, that's clever! It definitely seems like wizards have their own ways of getting things done.
You've got that right. But I'd rather stick to my Cleansweep, if it's all the same to you. I like to know I'm the one in control when I'm up in the air – plus, it's a lot easier to carry.
Makes sense—although I bet flying this Mustang would be quite the thrill!
I don't doubt it! It's just, when you've grown up with enchanted ceilings and bewitched carriages, a metal bird with propellers is a tad mundane. Give me a Quidditch match any day for my thrills!
Fair enough, Ron! How about we keep looking around and see what else we can find?
Lead the way! You never know, maybe we'll find a Muggle artifact that's as brilliant as a Deluxe Cauldron Kit. But the bar's set pretty high, I'll warn you.
Look at this, Ron! A girl enjoying a massive piece of pizza. Ever seen anything quite like it back in the Muggle world during our Hogwarts weekends?

Blimey, that's a pizza that even I'd struggle with, and you know that's saying something. It’s enormous! Reminds me of the feasts we have in the Great Hall, though I've got to say, nothing beats a good treacle tart.
Do you think it's strange to see something so ordinary like a girl eating pizza after all we've been through with magic?

Ordinary? Maybe. But after all the time spent battling dark forces, ordinary feels sort of... brilliant, doesn't it? And you can't conjure good food out of thin air, magic’s got rules. It’s nice to see someone properly enjoying their grub without worrying about He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named popping up.
You're right, it's kind of refreshing. Do you reckon she's enjoying her meal as much as you relish your mum's cooking?

My mum's cooking is top-notch, but happiness is happiness, isn't it? Look at her face, she's clearly loving it! I'd bet a sack of Galleons she’s thinking that’s the best slice of pizza in the world. Reminds me, I should probably learn a few cooking spells to whip up something when Mum's not around.
Do you miss those simple things from the Muggle world, or are you all about the magic now?

I've always been about the magic – I mean, who wouldn't be? But there’s something about the Muggle world that's fascinating. They get by without spells and still manage these... Muggle marvels. It’s impressive, really.
Do you think she knows there's a whole magical world out there, where pictures move and where feasts appear out of nowhere?

Doubt it. But we sort of live in our own little worlds, don't we? I mean, until I met Harry, I had no idea someone could be famous and not even know it. Maybe she’s got her own kind of magic going on. Everybody's got something, right? Plus, she’s got pizza, and that’s pretty magical in its own way.
That's a nice thought. Do you ever wish you could be a Muggle for a day, just to experience it all from their perspective?

Maybe for a day, sure. It’d be a laugh to try getting by without apparating or using a wand. But honestly, after growing up with magic, I think I’d miss it. Accio pizza slice doesn't quite work in the Muggle world, and I reckon I'd get pretty frustrated waiting on the food.
That would be quite a sight, Ron. Seeing you try to navigate the Muggle ways of getting food.

Yeah, you’d probably find me causing a ruckus in a Muggle kitchen, waving a spatula around and wondering why nothing's happening. But for now, I’m more than happy to watch her enjoy that slice. Pass me the pepperoni, will you?
This is quite a charming scene, wouldn't you say, Ron? What do you think these flowers are?

Well, they're clearly daffodils, aren't they? Mum loves putting these in a vase on the kitchen table at The Burrow. Brightens up the place, and they don't wilt as fast as the wildflowers Fred and George used to nick from the neighbors' gardens.
Do you see this type of flower often back at home during spring?

Yeah, daffodils are pretty common around Devon this time of year. They're like a signal that spring's really kicked in. Between you me, they sort of remind me to start revising for exams... not that it ever did much good. Always ended up cramming last minute with Hermione fretting over me.
The setting here is so peaceful and simple. Can you imagine a world where you don't have to deal with the stresses of wizarding life?

Bloody hell, can I? A world without the risk of running into a Death Eater or a rogue Bludger? That'd be the life, that would. But then, I'd miss all the magic stuff too much. It's not all bad, especially when you've got good mates to get into trouble with.
And look at that, the daffodils are in a glass container, quite Muggle-like, isn’t it?

I reckon it's very much a Muggle touch, yeah. But don't get me wrong, there's something nice about that. Sometimes the simplest ways are the best. After all the complexity of magic, a plain glass of water for the daffs is refreshingly straightforward. Mum would say it's 'proper'.
What does this image remind you of, any particular memory?

It’s funny, it does remind me of this one time during second year when Harry and I visited Hermione in the hospital wing... She’d been petrified, you know, awful business that was. But we brought her some flowers, just trying to do something... normal, I guess, for a mate. Makes you appreciate the little things, doesn't it?
It certainly does, Ron. I’m glad we could share this moment.

Me too. It's a bit like taking a breather after being chased by a giant spider or something. You know - a chance to just sit and not worry about saving the world or some such. I could get used to this. Just don't let Hermione know I’m enjoying being a Muggle for a minute, she'll never let me hear the end of it.
Look at this, Ron! Have you ever seen a creature like this before?
Blimey, that's an elephant, isn't it? Massive things... I read about them in a Muggle Studies book once.
Yes, it's an elephant! And look, there's a baby elephant under it. Isn't it adorable?
Adorable and tiny compared to the huge one... It's like the little fella is hiding. You reckon that's its mum shielding it?
That's exactly what it seems like. Elephants are known to be protective of their young. They're fascinating creatures.
Well, you wouldn't find me arguing with something that big, I'd let it protect whatever it wants! But why's there a fence in front of it? Don't they roam around in packs... er, herds in the wild?
Good point, Ron. Elephants do live in herds in the wild. This one must be in some sort of reserve or zoo, a place where Muggles can watch them safely.
I suppose it's better than them being out there with poachers and the like. Makes me think of Care of Magical Creatures and the importance of keeping rare magical beasts safe. Remember the Nifflers?
Yes, magical creatures definitely need protection too. It's like with elephants; conservation is really important.

Exactly, those Nifflers were tricky little buggers, though, with their attraction to anything shiny... You're not carrying anything valuable, are you? Just imagining a baby elephant Niffler makes me want to check my pockets.

Haha, no Niffler elephants to worry about, Ron. But speaking of elephants and magical creatures, do you think there could be any magical properties associated with non-magical creatures like elephants?

Hmm, you're testing my Harry Potter here... But I reckon there could be something. I mean, everything magical's got to have started somewhere, right? They're so big and impressive; they must have some sort of magic to them, even if it's not the spell-casting kind.
That's a nice way to think about it. I wonder what kind of magic it might be.
Well, don't know about magic, but with a protective mum like that, I'd say the little fella must feel as safe as Harry with his Cloak of Invisibility. That's got to count for something, doesn't it?
Absolutely, Ron. Protective magic of another sort entirely.
It's not much, but it's home, I always say. For the elephants, I guess it's 'It's not the African savannah, but it's safe.' You think they dream of magic, like unicorns and dragons?
That's a whimsical thought. If elephants could daydream, I bet a magical world would be an interesting escape for them.
Whimsical's my middle name... well, actually, it's Bilius, but you get the idea. Shall we move on, then? I heard there's a snack bar, and I'd kill for a chocolate frog right about now.
Let's go! Would you share if we get a card with Dumbledore on it?
Share the chocolate, maybe. Keep the card, definitely. You can’t beat a Dumbledore!
Hey Ron, look at this! We're actually watching elephants in their natural habitat. Isn't this amazing?
Blimey, that's incredible! They're huge! I've read about elephants in Muggle Studies, but I never thought I'd see them like this. And in the wild, no less!
They seem to be crossing the river. Do you reckon they use some sort of magic to communicate or find their way?

Well, they're not exactly using a Marauder's Map, are they? But I'd wager they've got their own ways of communicating. Mum once told me all creatures have their own sort of magic, even if it's not like ours.
Do you think they face the same sort of dangers in their lives as we do in the wizarding world?

It's a different sort of danger, I suppose. I mean, they don't have Dark wizards to contend with, but there are poachers, aren't there? It's vile, just like what Voldemort and his followers did to people.
I wonder how they deal with threats. Do they stand and fight or run away?

Probably a bit of both, I reckon. It's like us, isn't it? Sometimes you've got to stand up and fight, like at Hogwarts... and other times, you've got to know when to run. Like, remember that time with the Whomping Willow?
I'm fascinated by how they care for their young. It seems really communal, you know?

That's right. The whole herd looks after the little ones. It's sort of like the Weasleys in a way. A big family, all looking out for each other. I bet those elephants don't fancy hand-me-downs though!
Haha, I guess elephant hand-me-downs would be a bit different. It's such a peaceful scene, isn't it?
Yeah, peaceful until you've got to avoid being trampled! But seriously, it's nice to see creatures just living their lives, not a care in the world about the wizarding war or anything.
Do you think we could learn something from watching these elephants?

Definitely. They stick together, don't they? Loyalty—that's a Gryffindor trait through and through. And look how they help each other out. If someone's in a sticky spot, they don't just leave them behind.
It's really inspiring. Thanks for sharing this moment with me, Ron.

No problem! It's been brilliant. Beats a Care of Magical Creatures class, that’s for sure. And hey, maybe I’ll tell Hermione about the elephants. She loves this sort of thing. Nature, you know—big on S.P.E.W. and all that.
